overview: Class 1 contributions employers have to pay for their employees, rates and categories to calculate how much to pay
title: National Insurance Contributions (NICs) for your employees

table.body:
For all employees earning more than £7,606 a year you have to deduct Class 1 National Insurance contributions (NICs) from their pay. You also pay a direct contribution yourself. The exact amounts depend on:

- how much an employee earns
- their National Insurance category (this depends on their circumstances)

You have to keep National Insurance records for all employees earning more than £5,564.

##National Insurance on benefits
If you provide any [employee benefits](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits "employee benefits") (eg health insurance, company cars) you might have to deduct Class 1A National Insurance contributions from these. [This depends on the benefit](/expenses-and-benefits-a-to-z "Expenses and benefits A to Z").

Some small or irregular benefits can be brought together in a single annual payment called a [PAYE Settlement Agreement](/paye-settlement-agreements "PAYE Settlement Agreements"). You'll have to pay Class 1B National Insurance on these.

##Workers not on your payroll

Anyone who does work for you but is not on your payroll (eg self employed, volunteers), is responsible for paying their own National Insurance contributions.

*[NICs]: National Insurance Contributions
*[PAYE]: Pay As You Earn
*[HMRC]: HM Revenues & Customs
table.title: Overview

table.body:
##Calculating National Insurance Contributions
You calculate your employees’ National Insurance contributions (NICs) using your Pay As You Earn (PAYE) payroll system. 

You’ll need each employee’s [National Insurance category](/national-insurance-contributions-nics-for-employers/national-insurance-category-letters "National Insurance category") for this.

If you do your payroll manually and don’t use software, the [HMRC National Insurance calculator](http://nicecalculator.hmrc.gov.uk/Class1NICs1.aspx "HMRC National Insurance calculator"){:rel="external"} will help you calculate the amounts you need to enter into your payroll. 

HMRC also has information on [payroll and NICs calculations.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/paye/payroll/index.htm "payroll and NICs calculations"){:rel="external"}

##Making payments
Most employers pay Class 1 NICs by direct debit, which you set up when you register as an employer with HMRC.

If you don’t want to pay by direct debit there are other ways of [paying Class 1](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/payinghmrc/paye.htm "paying Class 1"){:rel="external"}. 

HMRC also has information on [paying Class 1A.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/payinghmrc/class1anics.htm "paying Class 1A"){:rel="external"} and on [paying Class 1B.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/payinghmrc/psa.htm "paying class 1B"){:rel="external"} 


*[NICs]: National Insurance Contributions
*[PAYE]: Pay As You Earn
*[HMRC]: HM Revenues & Customs
table.title: Calculating and paying National Insurance contributions

table.body:
National Insurance Contributions (NICs) Class 1 are part of your monthly Pay As You Earn (PAYE) payments.

Class 1A contributions on expenses and benefits are calculated separately at the end of the year. These have to be in HM Revenues & Customs' (HMRC) account by 22 July if you pay electronically or by 19 July if you send a cheque. 

If you pay Class 1B on employee benefits your payments have to be in HMRC's account by 22 October (19 October if you pay by cheque). 

HMRC has detailed information on [National Insurance payment deadlines.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/paye/file-or-pay/payments/deadlines.htm#2 "national insurance payment deadlines"){:rel="external"}


*[NICs]: National Insurance contributions
*[PAYE]: Pay As You Earn
*[HMRC]: HM Revenues & Customs
table.title: Deadlines for NICs payments

table.body:
You need to know an employee’s National Insurance category to work out how much to pay for them. If you use Pay As You Earn (PAYE) payroll software it’ll ask you for the category letter to calculate your contributions.

An employee's NI category letter depends on whether they have a separate (contracted-out) pension scheme and opted out of paying into the State Pension.

^Most employees are category A or D.^

##Employees not in contracted-out pension schemes

Category letter |	Employee group 
- | -
A | All employees apart from the ones in groups B, C and J in this table.
B | Married women and widows entitled to pay reduced Class 1 contributions.
C | Employees over the State Pension age.
J | Employees who can defer full Class 1 payments because they're already paying NI contributions in another job.

##Employees in a salary-related contracted-out scheme

Category letter | Employee group
- | - 
D | All employees apart from the ones in groups E, C and L in this table.
E | Married women and widows entitled to pay reduced Class 1 contributions.
C | Employees over the State Pension age.
L | Employees who can defer full Class 1 payments because they're already paying NI contributions in another job.

##Employees in a money-purchase contracted-out scheme

This kind of scheme ended in April 2012 but some of your employees might still be part of one.

Category letter | Employee group
- | - 
F | Tax years before 2012-13 only:  all employees apart from the ones in groups G, C and S in this table.
G | Tax years before 2012-13 only: married women and widows entitled to pay reduced Class 1 NICs.
C | Employees over the State Pension age.
S | Tax years before 2012-13 only: employees who can defer full Class 1 payments because they're already paying NI contributions in another job.


*[NI]: National Insurance
*[PAYE]: Pay As You Earn
*[HMRC]: HM Revenues & Customs
table.title: National Insurance category letters

table.body:
There are 2 types of Class 1 National Insurance Contributions (NICs):

- primary contributions - what you deduct from your employee’s pay 
- secondary contributions - what you pay towards an employee’s contributions 

Both types of contributions depend on: 

- the employee’s [National Insurance category](/national-insurance-contributions-nics-for-employers/national-insurance-category-letters "National Insurance category")
- the employee’s earnings 

##Employee Class 1 contributions rates (primary) for the tax year 2012-13

The following table shows the amount you have to deduct from your employee's pay. This depends on their earnings. No deductions need to be made on earnings below £5,564 a year.

Category letter | £5,564 to £7,488 a year | £7,489 to £7,605 a year | £7,606 to £40,040 a year | £40,041 to £42,475 a year | Balance over £42,475 a year
- | - | - | - | - | -
A | 0% | 0% | 12% | 12% | 2%
B | 0% | 0% | 5.85% | 5.85% | 2%
C | NIL | NIL | NIL | NIL | NIL
D | 0% | 0% | 10.60%	 | 12% | 2%
E | 0% | 0% | 5.85% | 5.85% | 2%
J | 0% | 0% | 2% | 2% | 2%
L | 0% | 0% | 2% | 2% | 2%

##Statutory pay rebate for statutory payments

Category letter |  £5,564 to £7,488 a year | £7,489 to £7,605 a year
- | - | -
A | N/A | N/A
B | N/A | N/A
C | N/A | N/A

##Employer Class 1 contribution rates (secondary) for the tax year 2012-13

The following table shows the amount you have to pay towards an employee’s National Insurance. This depends on their earnings. No payments have to be made on earnings below £5,564 a year.

- | - | - | - | - | - | -
A | 0% | 13.80%	 | 13.80% | 13.80% | 13.80% | N/A
B | 0% | 13.80% | 13.80% | 13.80% | 13.80% | N/A

D | 0% | 10.40% | 10.40% | 13.80% | 13.80% | 3.40%
E | 0% | 10.40% | 10.40% | 13.80% | 13.80% | 3.40%
J | 0% | 13.80%	 | 13.80% | 13.80% | 13.80% | N/A

##Class 1A and Class 1B rates
The 2012-13 rate for National Insurance on benefits for Class 1A and 1B is 13.8%.
